headline.seo: A Crusade and Some Diet Advice From That ‘Fat Band Boy’
headline.print_headline: A Crusade and Some Diet Advice From That ‘Fat Band Boy’
headline.main: A Crusade and Some Diet Advice From That ‘Fat Band Boy’

docs.lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton knows how hard his crusade to reduce childhood obesity will be, in part because he knows how hard his own struggles with weight have been.
docs.snippet: Former President Bill Clinton knows how hard his crusade to reduce childhood obesity will be, in part because he knows how hard his own struggles with weight have been.

headline.main: Seduced By Snacks? No, Not You

docs.abstract: Prof Brian Wansink performs quirky experiments in psychology of overindulgence; most people swear they are not influenced by packaging or variety offered, but Wansink offers hard data to dieticians, food executives and others who use it to get people to eat differently; research shows that people make more than 200 food decisions each day, and are often outwitted by savvy marketers; several experiments described; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE almost always think they are too smart for Prof. Brian Wansink's quirky experiments in the psychology of overindulgence. When it comes to the slippery issues of snacking and portion control, no one thinks he or she is the schmo who digs deep into the snack bowl without thinking, or orders dessert just because a restaurant plays a certain kind of music.
docs.snippet: PEOPLE almost always think they are too smart for Prof. Brian Wansink's quirky experiments in the psychology of overindulgence.      When it comes to the slippery issues of snacking and portion control, no one thinks he or she is the schmo who digs...

docs.lead_paragraph: This is becoming the decade when food once thought to be good for you is the new bad and vice versa.
docs.snippet: This is becoming the decade when food once thought to be good for you is the new bad and vice versa.

docs.abstract: Article on changes to public school menus across New York metropolitan region as districts begin to comply with new federal law requiring them to develop 'wellness policies' outlining nutrition and exercise goals before classes began this fall; local school boards vary enormously in how they are interpreting federal mandate, with some making significant changes and others doing almost nothing; photos (L)
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: ''I miss the cookies and the fries,'' Max Gold-Landzberg said. Sitting in the cafeteria at John Jay High School in Cross River, N.Y., Max, 17, a senior, chomped on a roast beef and cheese sandwich on a whole wheat roll.
docs.snippet: ''I miss the cookies and the fries,'' Max Gold-Landzberg said.      Sitting in the cafeteria at John Jay High School in Cross River, N.Y., Max, 17, a senior, chomped on a roast beef and cheese sandwich on a whole wheat roll.
